Borrower  People’s Republic of China (PRC)

Theme: Sustainable economic growth

Assessment  the  summary  was  circulated  to  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)

Project Description  The  Lanzhou–Chongqing  Railway  (LCR)  Development  Project  is  in 
Chongqing  municipality  and  the  northwestern  part  of  Sichuan  and 
Gansu  provinces—a  relatively  poor  area.  It  is  designed  to  promote 
sustainable economic growth by building 820 kilometers (km) of railway 
line from Lanzhou, the capital city of Gansu province, to Chongqing. The 
Project will (i) develop an efficient, safe, affordable, and environmentally 
sustainable railway transport system in the region; and (ii) help create 
more employment and income-generating opportunities, thus benefiting 
poor residents.  
   
Rationale  The  Project  reflects  ADB’s  operational  strategy  for  the  PRC  railway 
sector,  which  includes  reducing  railway  network  constraints  and 
promoting sustainable economic growth in poor areas not served by 
railways.  The  Project  is  also  in  line  with  the  Government’s  western 
development strategy of providing less-developed regions with better 
infrastructure  to  facilitate  economic  growth,  thereby  giving  people  a 
better opportunity to improve their living standards.  
The  interior  regions  of  the  PRC  have  not  benefited  as  much  from 
economic  growth  and  reforms  as  the  east  coast;  in  fact,  the  gap 
between  economic  and  social  development  in  those  regions  has 
increased. Transport constraints and high logistics costs contribute to 
the economic disparities between the regions and prevent the western 
region from capitalizing on its comparative advantages. 
The Project will be (i) the first north–south railway line linking Chongqing 
municipality and Gansu, Shaanxi, and Sichuan provinces; and (ii) the 
shortest north–south corridor linking Lanzhou, Baoji, Yinchuan, Xining, 
Xinjiang, and other major cities in the north to Chongqing, Chengdu, 
Guiyang,  Kunming,  and  other  ports  and  cities  in  the  south.  The 
proposed alignment for the LCR is shorter by 295 km and 600 km than 
the two existing routes between Lanzhou and Chongqing. Traversing 
Gansu, Shaanxi, and Sichuan provinces and Chongqing municipality, 
the  proposed  railway  line  will  connect  with  the  Baotou–Yinchuan–
Lanzhou in the northeast; Urumqi–Lanzhou in the northwest on its way 
to Kazakhstan and Europe; Shanghai–Wuhan–Ankang in the east, at

ii 
Guangyuan;  Shanghai–Wuhan–Yichang–Daxian–Chengdu  in  the 
center;  Yichang–Lichuan–Chongqing,  Chongqing–Guiyang,  and 
Chongqing–Kunming in the south on its way to Viet Nam, Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic, and Southeast Asia; and the main lines Xi’an–
Chongqing  in  the  north,  and  Chongqing–Chengdu  in  the  west.  The 
Project will also help promote regional cooperation, as this north–south 
corridor will be the shortest linking the Greater Mekong Subregion to 
Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  countries  through  the 
PRC. 
   
  The project company, a joint venture of the Ministry of Railways (MOR) 
and the Chongqing municipal, Gansu provincial, and Sichuan provincial 
governments, will have substantial managerial and financial autonomy. It 
will  help  change  railway  enterprises  from  cost  centers  in  a  planned 
economy  to  profit  centers  in  an  increasingly  competitive  transport 
market.  The  components  have  been  formulated  in  line  with  MOR’s 
railway development plan for 2004. 
   
Impact and  The impact of the Project will be an improved transport system in the 
Outcome  region  that  supports  socioeconomic  development  and  the  western 
development  strategy.  Providing  economic  railway  transportation  in 
unserved, less-developed, and poor areas will help create the conditions 
for local resource development, more jobs, and higher incomes and thus 
raise living standards in the project area.  
 
Project  preparation  was  participatory.  All  the  main  stakeholders—
various affected people, potential beneficiaries, village leaders, women’s 
groups,  local  ethnic  bureaus,  and  local  governments  in  the  project 
area—were extensively consulted. Household surveys and participatory 
workshops in the project area elicited public opinion about the Project 
and useful information for the social and environmental assessments. 
 
The Project has the following components: (i) the construction of 820 km 
of double-track electrified standard-gauge class I railway from Lanzhou 
to Chongqing; (ii) the construction of 31 new railway stations complete 
with facilities; (iii) the provision of modern technology and equipment, 
among  other  initiatives,  to  improve  safety;  (iv)  the  introduction  of  a 
signaling, communication, and management information system; (v) the 
provision  of  training  in  the  use  and  maintenance  of  the  modern 
equipment;  (vi)  land  acquisition  and  resettlement;  (vii)  environmental 
protection  and  mitigation  of  adverse  environmental  effects; 
(viii) consulting  services  for  construction  supervision,  monitoring  and 
evaluation,  and  marketing  and  business  development;  and  (ix)  the 
strengthening  of  institutional  capabilities.  Project  implementation  will 
require these key inputs: civil works, equipment, consultants, and MOR 
and project company staff.  
   
Project Investment  The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $8,608.9 million.

Implementation  The Project will be implemented over 7 years. The Foreign Capital and 
Arrangements  Technical Import Center under MOR will coordinate the tasks of the 
project  management  office  and  be  responsible  for  procurement, 
withdrawals,  and  reporting  to  ADB.  The  project  company,  the 
Implementing  Agency,  will  manage  and  run  the  project  railway,  and 
develop  and  implement  adequate  and  transparent  business 
development mechanisms, and accounting and reporting systems.  
   
Procurement  MOR  will  procure  ADB-financed  components  according  to  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time), and 
other items according to government procedures acceptable to ADB.  
   
Consulting  The ADB loan will finance 10 person-months of international consulting 
Services  services  to  strengthen  the  institutional,  marketing,  and  business 
development functions of the project company. The consultants will be 
recruited  according  to  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). In addition, MOR will hire and 
finance  the  services  of  national  consultants  for  project  design, 
construction  supervision,  construction  quality  control,  environmental 
supervision,  procurement,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  the 
safeguard aspects of the Project. 
 
Project Benefits  The Project will (i) provide the shortest land route between Lanzhou, 
and Beneficiaries  Longnan, Guangyuan, and Chongqing—key economic centers of Gansu 
and Sichuan provinces and Chongqing municipality—lowering transport 
costs  for  railway  users  and  cutting  travel  distances  and  times; 
(ii) increase the corridor’s capacity, to the benefit of consumers and 
producers of goods and services, who can avail themselves of timely 
and efficient transport services and lower logistics costs; (iii) generate 
direct and indirect employment and other income-earning opportunities 
in the project influence area (much local unskilled labor will be hired to 
build and operate the railway); (iv) broaden access to markets for an 
area that lacks cost-efficient transportation services; and (v) stimulate 
local development through small-business opportunities, tourism, and 
railway station area and other infrastructure development.

iv 
The major project beneficiaries will be (i) the Government, which stands 
to gain from improved safety and a lower energy bill; (ii) passengers, 
including tourists, for whom travel will be affordable, faster, and safer; 
(iii) freight users, who switch from the existing road and benefit from 
more affordable, faster, and safer trips; (iv) local residents, who will pay 
less for goods and services transported by the project railway; (v) local 
labor hired to build the railway, supply materials during construction, and 
load and unload goods during operation; (vi) local farmers, who can sell 
their products at market prices without having to pay a high margin to a 
transport intermediary; (vii) manufacturers and traders, who can set up 
businesses, produce more, and transport their goods and services by 
the  railway;  and  (viii) local  governments,  which  will  have  greater 
opportunity for local area development and higher tax revenues. 
 
The Project will benefit about 16.8 million people living in the project 
area. The poverty and social assessment looked at the 28 counties and 
districts in the area, including 15 designated national poverty counties 
and 2,897 designated poverty villages. About 72% of the beneficiaries 
are rural, and 17% are poor, with an annual net income per capita of 
less than CNY1,000. The links between poverty, difficult topography, 
and poor transport systems are apparent in the project area. Poverty is 
often caused by geographic remoteness and isolation, limited transport 
access, high transport costs, and poor access to market information, as 
well as limited access to health, education, and other social services. 
 
  The Project will give rise to more jobs and income opportunities. The 
468,000  or  so  person-years  of  work  during  construction  will  provide 
direct employment for over 234,000 poor people, including women and 
ethnic  minorities.  Railway  station  area  development  will  boost  the 
incomes of communities and produce tax revenues. The development of 
small businesses, local industry, and tourism through the Project will 
increase opportunities in the future for local people. Consultations with 
local people in the project area indicated strong support for the Project. 
 
The  Project  is  financially  and  economically  sustainable.  The  6.98% 
financial internal rate of return exceeds the 2.74% weighted average 
cost of capital. The economic internal rate of return is 17.09%.  
 
The increased tax revenues from the economic development induced by 
the Project will help finance improvements in social service facilities and 
basic infrastructure. 
   
Risks and  The  construction  of  the  railway,  in  mountainous  areas,  presents  a 
Assumptions  significant  technical  challenge.  Construction  could  be  delayed,  cost 
  more than expected, compromise the health and safety of workers, and 
adversely  affect  the  environment.  These  potential  risks  have  been 
assessed and mitigating measures based on lessons learned from other 
railway projects in the PRC have been provided.  
 
Resettlement will cause the relocation of about 12,000 households. The 
railway  alignment  was  selected  to  minimize  resettlement,  where

v 
possible.  Those  resettled  will  be  given  preference  in  hiring  for 
construction,  in  the  supply  of  local  materials,  in  the  allocation  of 
commercial space near railway stations, and in job training. To mitigate 
the  potential  social  risks,  resettlement  will  be  implemented  by  local 
governments and closely monitored and supervised. 
 
Intermodal competition between railways and roads will pose market 
risks  for  the  project  railway.  However,  the  existing  road  is  in  poor 
condition  and  congested,  and  the  congestion  will  only  get  worse. 
Passengers and freight shippers surveyed pointed out the advantages of 
railways over other transport modes: lower fares, shorter travel times, 
safety, and punctuality. The increasing commercial orientation of the 
joint-venture railway will help lessen the market risks. 
   
Technical  A technical assistance grant not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 
Assistance  from  the  Clean  Energy  Fund  under  the  Clean  Energy  Financing 
Partnership Facility is proposed to assist MOR in preparing the Railway 
Sector Energy Efficiency Strategy. The technical assistance grant will 
support  (i)  an  analysis  of  the  energy  efficiency  of  the  PRC  railway 
sector, (ii) the identification of areas where energy efficiency can be 
improved, and (iii) the recommendation of actions and technologies that 
can be adopted. Areas where energy efficiency can be improved will be 
prioritized and a pipeline of priority lending projects for energy efficiency 
in the PRC railway sector, some of which can be supported by ADB, will 
be recommended. 
 
Consultants  financed  by  ADB  will  be  recruited  according  to  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). Consulting firms will be selected through international competition 
after submitting simplified technical proposals, which will be evaluated 
on the basis of a quality–cost ratio of 80:20.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Lanzhou–Chongqing  Railway  (LCR) 
Development Project. The report also describes proposed administration of technical assistance 
(TA) for preparing the Railway Sector Energy Efficiency Strategy, and if the Board approves the 
proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
The design and monitoring framework for the Project is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  From 1978, when market-oriented economic reforms were introduced in the PRC, to 
2007, the country went through sustained rapid economic growth, and a resulting rapid increase 
in demand for transportation. Passenger transport grew by 9% yearly and freight transport by 
7.6%. Railways are the principal mode of freight transport in the PRC, with 47.5% of total freight 
ton-kilometers (ton-km) in 2006, followed by 27.9% for inland waterways and sea-to-shore 
shipping, 21.1% for roads, 3.3% for pipelines, and 0.2% for civil aviation. In 2006, road traffic 
accounted for 52.8% of total passenger-kilometers (pass-km), followed by railways with 34.5%, 
civil aviation with 12.3%, and coastal and inland waterways with 0.4%. 
 
3.  The railway is the primary mode of long-distance and bulk transport. At the end of 2007, 
the PRC’s 78,000 route-kilometers (route-km) of railways comprised 63,600 km of national 
railways and 14,400 km of joint-venture and local railways. The Ministry of Railways (MOR) runs 
the state-owned national railway as an integrated system. The joint-venture and local railways, 
regional  lines  within  provincial  boundaries,  are  built  under  provincial  government  or  MOR 
sponsorship to serve local needs and interconnect with the national railway network. Despite its 
large size, however, the railway network does not provide adequate coverage for the country’s 
population and land area.1  
 
4.  PRC railways have the highest freight transport density in the world and second-highest 
passenger transport density after Japan. Locomotive turnover is the highest in the world. From 
1978 to 2007, railway freight increased from 535 billion ton-km to 2,380 billion ton-km, or by 
5.28%  yearly,  and  passenger  traffic  grew  by  6.74%  yearly,  from  109 billion  pass-km  to 
722 billion pass-km. For passenger trips, the average railway journey increased from 134 km in 
1978 to 532 km in 2007, compared with road travel, which grew from 35 km to 55 km over the 
same period. For freight, the average railway journey in 2007 was 757 km, compared with 
65 km for road transport. Yet, despite such growth rates, railway capacity has lagged behind 
demand  because  of  system  constraints.  Given  the  railways’  important  role  in  economic 
transportation, these constraints, if not removed, will continue to hamper efficient economic 
growth. The Government’s aggressive plan to improve railways includes network expansion and 
construction in underserved areas. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                 
1  Network density per 1,000 square km of land is one-third that of India and one-tenth that of Japan.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
1.  Government Strategy  
 
5.  The Government’s railway development policy puts emphasis on (i) removing constraints 
and expanding the system, (ii) encouraging the construction of joint-venture and local railways 
to promote the development of local economies, (iii) improving the efficiency and safety of the 
existing  system  by  using  new  technology  and  modern  management  tools  in  planning  and 
operation, (iv) reducing operating subsidies through appropriate pricing and commercialization 
of  services,  (v)  initiating  institutional  and  structural  reforms  to  increase  autonomy  and 
accountability, and (vi) encouraging nongovernment investment in infrastructure and related 
services.  
 
6.  In 2004, the State Council approved a railway development plan for the period up to 
2020. The plan seeks to expand the railway network to 100,000 km by 2020. Increasing train 
speed is a major goal. Priority will be given to the development of railways in unserved areas 
and regions that lack transport and have remained less developed. Route network length in the 
western region of the PRC will increase by 16,000 km, to 40,000 km, by 2020. To improve 
operating efficiency, MOR has begun to separate passenger and freight trains on key rail 
corridors.2  
 
7.  The 11th Five-Year Plan (2006–2010) highlights railway development and accelerated 
railway construction. It foresees (i) the construction of 17,000 km of new lines, for a total 
network length of 92,000 route-km; and (ii) the conversion of 45% of the network length into 
double-track  electrified  railway.  The  plan  seeks  to  (i)  build  a  dedicated  passenger  railway 
network through the construction of 7,000 km of passenger-dedicated lines by 2010; (ii) develop 
coal transport corridors by increasing the capacity of the existing lines; (iii) expand the railway 
network in the poor western region (to 34,000 km); (iv) build international corridors at the 
southwest and northwest borders; and (v) develop a nationwide intermodal container network. A 
total investment of CNY1.5 trillion (about $200 billion)—CNY1.25 trillion for construction and 
CNY250 billion for rolling stock—is planned in the 11th Five-Year Plan, of which a total of CNY 
465.2 billion has been spent in 2006 and 2007 (Appendix 3). 
 
2.  Asian Development Bank Strategy and Sector Experience 
 
8.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) strategy for the railway sector is centered on 
helping (i) expand the railway system by constructing new lines in unserved, less-developed 
areas; (ii) modernize railways and increase safety and capacity, to improve efficiency on key 
routes; (iii) commercialize railway operations to sustain efficient operations; (iv) promote energy 
conservation and environmental sustainability; and (v) increase railway competitiveness in the 
transport sector through restructuring and reform. ADB, the lead development partner in the 
PRC  railway  sector,  has  directed  its  energies  to  the  development  of  railways  in  poor,

3.  Policy Dialogue  
 
9.  Policy dialogue has been a feature of ADB assistance to the railway sector and has 
effectively complemented the lending operations. Since 2002, ADB has actively engaged MOR, 
the  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission,  and  the  Ministry  of  Finance  in  policy 
dialogue and discussion and has reached broad agreement on reforms as an engine for the 
further development of the railways. The railway development plan defines the major goals for 
the  PRC  railways  to  2020,  and  generally  conforms  with  ADB’s  strategic  agenda.  MOR’s 
proposed  reform  agenda  under  this  plan  involves  (i)  studying  and  learning  from  the  best 
international practices, (ii) separating core operations from noncore transportation businesses, 
(iii) streamlining  the  staff,  (iv)  reforming  the  railway  investment  and  financing  system,  and 
(v) establishing specialized transportation companies.  
 
10.  MOR  has  taken  a  structured  approach  to  railway  reform.  In  1999,  under  a  new 
management concept—the asset operating liability system—MOR entered into management 
contracts with some railway administrations to improve profitability (as a pilot project). The 
contracts helped improve operating and financial performance; the approach was later extended 
to all the railway administrations. The separation of core and noncore businesses is a key 
element  of  MOR’s  restructuring  program.  The  total  number  of  employees  in  the  core 
transportation business was reduced from 1.89 million in 1997 to 1.41 million in 2006. In the 
noncore  transportation business,  five  large  companies  employing  616,500  staff  have  been 
divested. To provide jobs for redundant staff, by the end of 2006, MOR had set up 3,625 
diversified businesses (independent of the core transportation business) employing 321,544 
staff to supply equipment, goods, and services to the railway industry. In 1998, MOR began a 
cost-sharing scheme for health insurance and pensions for railway employees. In 2005, MOR 
completed the transfer of 822 primary and middle schools, 46 vocational schools, and 181 
nursery schools, as well as 260 hospitals and medical units, to local governments. One hundred 
branch lines totaling 7,800 km were separated to improve productivity and reduce operating 
losses. (The reform agenda matrix is in Appendix 4. Supplementary Appendix A includes a 
chronology of railway reforms.) 
 
11.  ADB  policy  dialogue  with  MOR  deals  primarily  with  (i)  poverty  reduction  as  the 
overarching  objective  of  ADB  operations,  (ii)  energy  conservation  and  environmental 
sustainability,  (iii) safety  improvements,  (iv)  sector  reforms,  (v)  marketing  and  business 
development,  and  (vi) private  sector  participation  and  nongovernment  financing.  Fourteen 
technical assistance (TA) grants totaling $6.6 million have been provided since 1989 for the 
development of the emergency management system on the PRC railway network, institutional 
development of dedicated passenger lines and local railways, tariff and organizational studies 
for the Jing–Jiu railway, enhancement of commercial and business operations, marketing and 
business  development,  human  resource  development,  and  improvement  of  financial 
management and accounting systems (Appendix 5). ADB, as the lead development partner, 
continues to emphasize further progress in those areas and coordinates closely with other

a.  Poverty Reduction 
 
12.  The  strategic  purpose  of  ADB  involvement  in  the  railway  sector  is  to  create  the 
conditions  for  sustainable  economic  growth  that  would  help  improve  living  standards.  The 
Project,  located  in  an  unserved  area,  would  spur  economic  growth  through  improved, 
cost-effective transport access. Identifying ways of intensifying the impact on poverty reduction 
is an integral part of project planning and design. To this end, there are provisions for (i) the 
preferential hiring of poor workers, including women, for the construction and operation of the 
LCR;4 (ii) the use of locally produced materials that meet the requirements of quality and 
economy (e.g., sand, stone, cement); (iii) railway station area development; (iv) the building of 
station access roads and construction access roads; and (v) support for the poverty reduction 
programs of local governments.5 The Project will finance the construction of access roads to be 
handed over to the local government after they are built. Local governments have a 5-year plan 
for improving the road network and transport services in the project area while the Project is in 
progress. These roads will reach all of the province-designated poverty villages. The Project 
and the development of local roads will increase the welfare gains for the poor, including women, 
and help spread the project benefits to the poverty villages. 
 
b.  Energy Conservation and Environmental Sustainability 
 
13.  Energy conservation and environmental sustainability have been important elements of 
the ADB policy dialogue with MOR since 2006, and are also identified as the two important 
areas of sustainable development in the 11th Five-Year Plan of the Government. ADB dialogue 
is helping to create awareness of these two issues and of factors like energy savings and 
environmental improvements in the performance evaluation of railway administrations and other 
entities. The dialogue encourages the use of clean energy and energy-efficient technologies 
and environmental improvements in railway construction, operation, and maintenance. ADB will 
assist MOR in drawing up a strategy for making the PRC railways more energy-efficient.6 
Fuel-efficient locomotives, double-stack container trains, “green corridors,” environment-friendly 
station  design  and  waste  disposal,  and  fuel-efficient,  environment-friendly  safety  and 
maintenance equipment are part of the project design. This area has been of mutual interest to 
other development partners such as the AFD, Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau (KfW), and the 
World Bank. Close coordination has been maintained with them.

c.  Safety Improvements 
 
14.  Safety  is  an  integral  part  of  providing  competitive,  high-quality,  and  reliable 
transportation  for  people  and  goods.  As  PRC  railways  have  modernized,  introduced  new 
concepts and technologies, and increased speeds, the safety needs have changed. The 11th 
Five-Year Plan of MOR recognizes this important aspect and seeks to attract foreign technology 
and know-how to meet these needs. ADB policy dialogue with MOR emphasizes the need for 
reforms  in  rail  network  operations,  including  safety  in  construction  and  in  operation  and 
maintenance. MOR and ADB support the objective of safety and security on PRC railways 
through the introduction of modern technologies, policy development, legislation, monitoring and 
enforcement, and outreach activities (Appendix 6). Since 2003, investments in railway safety 
have been part of ADB financing. ADB initiated dialogue on the need to adopt a sector-wide 
approach rather than a project-based approach to safety. A sector-wide approach is consistent 
with the network approach to train operations in the PRC and helps provide economies of scale, 
and better management of emergencies, accidents, and preventive maintenance. MOR has 
adopted the sector-wide approach to safety, and its safety and transportation departments have 
worked closely with ADB to develop a comprehensive plan for the institutional, investment, and 
training needs for safety in PRC railways. ADB provided a TA of $500,000 for the development 
of an emergency management system for PRC railways.7 In 2007, ADB approved a $100 million 
loan for improving safety on the PRC railway network.8  
 
d.  Sector Reforms 
 
15.  ADB is supporting the institutional reform of the railway sector to separate government 
and enterprise functions, giving full play to market forces and increasing the competitiveness of 
the railways. ADB has actively pursued (i) the separation of the core transport business from the 
noncore transport business, (ii) the segmentation of passenger and freight services, and (iii) the 
strengthening of the recently corporatized  specialized transportation companies. As part of 
ADB’s policy dialogue with MOR, three large companies handling containers, special goods, 
and express parcel have been set up.9 The establishment of passenger-dedicated corridors with 
a separate institutional structure is a key ADB intervention.10 With ADB assistance, institutional, 
marketing,  business  development,  and  technical  standards  are  being  worked  out  for  such 
initiatives and MOR officials are receiving capacity-building support.11  
 
16.  The streamlining of transportation and non-transportation staff is also being pursued. On 
18  March  2005,  under  a  major  restructuring  exercise,  MOR  abolished  41 sub-railway 
administration bureaus, thereby doing away with one tier of railway management. By the end of 
2007, the number of stations and sections had been reduced from 1,500 to 627. This move has 
trimmed the staff by more than 22,000 and helped rationalize operations, improve productivity,

4.  Lessons  
 
20.  The report on the evaluation of ADB assistance to the transport sector in the PRC17 
pronounced ADB’s program for railways a success. The report noted that ADB’s strategic 
priorities in the railway subsector were well aligned with the country’s needs. Its overall focus on 
building railways with modern technologies met the need to increase railway capacity and 
reduce the persistent gap between supply and demand as quickly and efficiently as possible. 
The priority given by ADB to improving efficiency and commercial orientation and its emphasis 
on policy restructuring and reform matched the evolving institutional reforms in railways. 
 
21.  Completed and ongoing ADB-financed railway projects in the PRC show the executing 
agencies’ strong commitment and generally satisfactory capabilities for project implementation 
(Appendix 7). The speed of implementation has generally exceeded expectations at appraisal, 
and agencies have generally complied with loan covenants. Resettlement and environmental 
management have been satisfactory. Audit covenants have been complied with in a timely 
manner,  and  the  audited  financial  statements  have  been  generally  acceptable.  Of  the  15 
ADB-supported railway projects, 10 have been completed, and 5 are being implemented. 
 
22.  The completed railway projects highlight the need to (i) ensure that the executing agency 
established  for  project  processing,  implementation,  and  operation  has  adequate  capacity; 
(ii) prepare realistic traffic forecasts; (iii) review network-wide constraints on traffic and the 
impact on project viability of existing and planned railway lines and other transportation modes 
that may compete with project facilities; (iv) make realistic resettlement projections at appraisal; 
and (v) finance railway projects with appropriately determined debt–equity ratios.  
 
23.  Previous  railway  projects  have  contributed  to  socioeconomic  development  in  their

inaccessible  areas;  (iv)  domestic  resource  mobilization  has  improved,  providing  additional

5.  Rationale 
 
24.  The  Project  will  (i)  enhance  capacity  and  reduce  the  bottlenecks  through  network 
development; (ii) improve energy efficiency and environmental sustainability by providing a 
more efficient and environment-friendly mode of transport in the corridor; (iii)  improve safety by 
providing a reliable and safe mode of transport; (iv) support the PRC railway development plan 
and the western region development strategy; and (v) promote pro-poor economic growth along 
the  railway  line  and  in  the  region,  thereby  reducing  poverty.  The  project  area  is  largely 
mountainous with abundant natural reserves of coal and other nonferrous materials, and a large 
manufacturing industry and tourist sites. But, despite the abundant natural resources, many 
living in the area are poor. Because of inadequate transport services and high costs, the 
economic growth needed to reduce rural poverty has not materialized. Local governments and 
people living in the project area see the railway as a key investment for addressing this problem.

higher speeds and greater safety on the railway network. When complete, the Project will 
provide a shorter link from northwest to southwest PRC, release capacity on the existing railway

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
29.  The  impact  of  the  Project  will  be  an  improved  transport  system  in  the  region  that 
supports socioeconomic development and the western development strategy. It will achieve this 
by  providing  efficient,  affordable,  environment-friendly,  and  energy-efficient  railway 
transportation in unserved, less-developed areas to create the conditions needed to develop 
local resources and generate employment and income-enhancing opportunities.  
 
B.  Outputs 
 
30.  The  Project  comprises  (i)  the  construction  of  820  km  of  double-track  electrified 
standard-gauge class I railway from Lanzhou to Chongqing; (ii) the construction of 31 new 
railway stations complete with facilities; (iii) the provision of modern technology and equipment, 
among  other  safety  initiatives;  (iv)  the  introduction  of  a  signaling,  communication,  and 
management information system; (v) the provision of training in the use and maintenance of the 
modern equipment; (vi) land acquisition and resettlement; (vii) environmental protection and 
mitigation  of  adverse  environmental  effects;  (viii)  consulting  services  for  construction 
supervision, monitoring and evaluation, and marketing and business development; and (ix) the 
strengthening of institutional capabilities. Civil works, equipment, consultants, and MOR and 
project company staff are the key inputs needed for project implementation.  
 
C.  Special Features

ahead on reforms are the key value additions of ADB participation. Given the huge investment 
needs of the Project, ADB has encouraged MOR to tap diverse financing sources. A financing 
arrangement of 50% in equity and 50% in long-term loans has been worked out. The three

B.  Economic Benefits 
 
57.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated through a comparison of the 
with- and without-Project situations. The Project will reduce the cost of transport to and from the 
poor central and northwestern part of Gansu, Shaanxi, and Sichuan provinces and Chongqing 
municipality, and will provide economic opportunities in the unserved areas of Gansu and 
Sichuan  provinces  (Supplementary  Appendix  D).  Economic  costs  include  construction, 
operation,  and  maintenance  costs,  and  the  value  of  agricultural  production  from  land  lost 
permanently. Economic benefits include (i) operating cost savings for freight and passenger 
traffic,  (ii)  time  savings  in  diverted  passenger  traffic  from  buses,  (iii)  transport  benefits 
generated, (iv) tourism benefits, (v) shipper savings because of increased railway competition, 
(vi)  road  accidents  avoided,  (vii)  pollution  reduction  benefits,  (viii)  energy  savings,  and 
(ix) national productivity benefits. The project EIRR is 17.09%, indicating that the Project is 
economically viable (Appendix 15). Sensitivity analysis confirms the robustness of the Project’s 
economic viability. Changes in the key variables, such as a 20% reduction in benefits, do not 
significantly affect economic viability. The total cost would have to increase by 23% over those 
estimated for the EIRR to fall below the cutoff rate of 12%. Freight benefits would have to fall by 
25% and passenger benefits by 175%. Given ADB’s experience in the PRC railway sector, 
variations of such magnitude are unlikely. Project risks were quantified through the statistical 
method,  i.e.,  considering  the  possible  value  for  key  variables  and  the  probability  of  their 
occurrence. The result shows that the EIRR will exceed 12%, with 100% probability. Distribution 
analysis, undertaken by determining the project effects for various beneficiaries, indicates that a 
large portion of net benefits will accrue to project users and the economy. 
 
C.  Financial Benefits  
 
58.  Financial projections prepared for the project company, according to ADB’s Financial 
Management and Analysis of Projects,32 assessed the financial viability and sustainability of the 
railway (Appendix 16). The projected financial statements indicate that financial revenues will be 
sufficient to cover operation and maintenance costs, income taxes, and debt service, and 
provide a reasonable rate of return. The financial evaluation was undertaken in real terms, in 
constant 2008 prices. The project cost estimates and financial projections in nominal terms were 
converted to real terms by adjusting for the projected effects of foreign and domestic inflation 
and currency fluctuation. Incremental costs and benefits were derived under with- and without-
Project scenarios. The financial internal rate of return, computed after tax, is 6.98%. This 
compares favorably with the weighted average cost of capital, also computed after tax, of 2.74%. 
The Project is both financially viable and sustainable. Sensitivity and risk analyses indicate that 
the financial internal rate of return for the Project is robust under most conditions. Consolidated 
financial statements for the project company have been prepared and the project company’s 
financial  performance  is  projected  to  be  sound  and  sustainable  over  the  operating  period 
(Appendix 16).

62.  The links between poverty, topography, and poor transport systems are apparent in the 
project area. Poverty in this area is caused by (i) adverse environmental and weather conditions 
and limited farmland (e.g., mountainous terrain, cold weather, water scarcity, and soil erosion); 
(ii) geographical remoteness and isolation, and high transport costs; (iii) limited access to credit 
for rural enterprises; (iv) lack of access to good social and health-care facilities; and (v) high 
cost of middle- and higher-level education. 
 
63.  About  468,000  person-years  of  work  will  be  created  for  unskilled  laborers  during 
construction. Of this total, 50% or more, or about 234,000 person-years, with total wages of 
CNY2,105 million, will be targeted at the poor. The estimated construction tax revenue to 
counties will be reallocated and used for a range of poverty reduction and social activities, 
including the mitigation of negative impact from HIV/AIDS or sexually transmitted infections 
(STIs), human trafficking, and on the environment. The construction of 31 new railway stations, 
to be connected to the road network accessible by all villages, including the poor, will create 
various jobs to help distribute the benefits in the project area. There will be sufficient space in 
and around the stations for local area development, and local governments will support the 
poor, women, ethnic groups, and other vulnerable people in selling local specialties and other 
goods and services. 
 
F.  Resettlement Impact  
 
64.  The project railway alignment will cross 275 villages as it passes through 94 townships 
and 22 districts and counties. An estimated 1,646 hectares of land will be permanently acquired, 
of which about 83% is now under cultivation; the rest is predominately forest land, residential 
land, or wasteland. The loss of land will partially affect 81,400 persons. The impact is spread 
thinly over a long narrow corridor.33 The Project will temporarily require about 1,390 hectares. 
                                                 
33 Land use for railways is much less than for a highway of equivalent capacity (a double-track railway has the 
cargo-carrying capacity of a 16-lane highway).

20 
Also, the Project will affect 1.19 million square meters of structures, of which 94% are residential 
structures; 42,250 persons (12,070 households) will have to be relocated. Aligning the railway 
away from urban areas, village centers, and other facilities, where possible, on the basis of 
consultations with communities, has minimized the impact.  
 
65.  MOR, in consultation with the local governments, has prepared a resettlement plan 
based  on  the  feasibility  study,  surveys  of  most  of  the  affected  villages,  2,700  household 
surveys, and consultations with local officials, village leaders, and affected households. Local 
government  land  administration  bureaus,  in  conjunction  with  railway  construction  support 
offices, will be responsible for implementing the resettlement; many activities will be carried out 
by township officials and village committees. The estimated resettlement cost is CNY2.1 billion, 
including land taxes, administration fees, and contingencies. The summary resettlement plan is 
in  Appendix  18.  MOR  and  municipal-level  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  offices,  in 
collaboration with the county resettlement offices, will be responsible for internal supervision 
and monitoring. An independent monitor will carry out the external monitoring and evaluation, 
and prepare monitoring reports for submission to MOR and ADB.  
 
G.  Impact on Ethnic Minorities  
 
66.  The  project  area  has  few  ethnic  minority  people  and  only  about  2%  of  the  total 
beneficiaries,  numbering  about  1,000,  may  be  adversely  affected  by  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement. The main ethnic group is Hui, who are quite integrated with the Han society. To 
give further support to ethnic minorities and mitigate any potential social risks, special measures 
have  been  included  in  the  resettlement  plan  and  social  development  action  plan  (SDAP) 
(Appendix 19). Ethnic minorities will be given preference in livelihood training and in jobs in 
construction  and  operation,  and  targeted  awareness  for  HIV/AIDS  and  other  transmissible 
diseases and human trafficking.  
 
H.  Social and Gender Aspects  
 
67.  Women and other vulnerable groups will benefit from the Project, and have equal access 
to project-generated employment and wages. The railway will generate demand for local labor 
and increase worker productivity and wages. Under PRC law, women are given equal rights in 
employment. The expansion of secondary and tertiary industries will help generate additional 
employment  opportunities  for  both  men  and  women.  Afforestation  activities  will  provide 
additional employment opportunities for women relatively close to their homes.  
 
68.  The construction and operation of the railway could have an impact on HIV/AIDS/STIs 
because of the large number of workers during construction. HIV/AIDS-infected persons in the 
project area are much fewer than in other parts of the PRC. Local governments have an active 
public information program for HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention, including the distribution of 
leaflets and posters, the airing of radio and television programs, and voluntary counseling and 
testing; these will be continued.  
 
69.  During  construction,  the  county  governments  along  the  alignment  will  raise  public 
awareness among workers and communities. MOR has experience in ensuring that contractors 
implement awareness and prevention programs during railway construction. Medical clinics 
have been established in the area of construction camps, and HIV/AIDS awareness campaigns 
and preventive measures for workers and communities have been organized during railway 
construction. These activities will continue during the construction and operation of the Project.

21 
Combined with increased awareness efforts by local government, they will ensure that the 
potential risks of HIV/AIDS/STI transmission are adequately managed. 
 
70.  An SDAP has been prepared in consultation with local governments to enhance the 
project  benefits,  ensure  that  the  adverse  effects  are  avoided  or  mitigated,  and  increase 
economic development benefits to the poor, women, ethnic minorities, and the vulnerable in an 
equitable and sustainable manner (Appendix 19). The SDAP will (i) enhance job opportunities 
for local people; (ii) provide training and vocational programs for the poor, women, ethnic 
minorities, and the vulnerable; (iii) support HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention programs; 
(iv) support  income  recovery  programs  for  people  affected  by  resettlement;  (v)  provide 
awareness  and  prevention  programs  for  safety  during  construction  and  operation;  and 
(vi) promote local economic development. The SDAP will be implemented with the participation 
of relevant government agencies at the local level, including poverty alleviation offices, the 
All-China  Women’s  Federation,  and  health,  civil  affairs,  labor,  and  ethnic  affairs  bureaus. 
Leading groups have been formed to continue the process of consultation and coordination 
among various agencies during implementation. 
 
I.  Risks and Assumptions 
 
71.  The Project has been formulated to minimize potential risks. Traffic demand has been 
estimated conservatively, on the basis of experience with previous railway projects. Sensitivity 
tests indicate that economic circumstances would have to become substantially adverse for the 
Project to lose economic viability. A potential risk is delay in implementation, which would delay 
the realization of benefits. MOR has successfully built railway lines, such as the Ganzhou–
Longyan, Hefei–Xi’an, and Jing–Jiu railways. Support for the Project and its preparation from 
the  Government,  MOR,  GPG,  SPG  and  CMG  will  help  reduce  the  potential  risk  of 
implementation delays. Environmental risks will be mitigated by measures in the environmental 
management plan (EMP) and will be closely monitored during project implementation. 
 
72.  The Project will cause the relocation of 12,070 households and partial loss of land for 
81,400 people. The resettlement plan includes good compensation standards, rehabilitation 
options, and preferential treatment for employment during construction, supply of local materials, 
allocation of commercial space near railway stations, and job training. The resettlement plan 
and SDAP will be closely monitored to ensure compliance with ADB’s social safeguard policies. 
 
73.  Intermodal competition among railways and roads will create market risks for the project 
railway. However, the existing road is already congested and capacity constraints are expected 
to worsen. Traffic surveys indicate that the railway has several advantages: lower fares, shorter 
travel times, higher safety, and improved punctuality. The increasing commercial orientation of 
the joint-venture railway will help lower the risks posed by intermodal competition. 
 
VI.  ASSURANCES 
 
74.  In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 
assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents. 
 
(i)  Reform measures. The Government will take necessary measures to continue 
implementation of the Railway Development Plan (2004) including (a) separating 
the core railway operations from noncore transportation business operations, 
(b) rationalizing  staff,  and  (c)  encouraging  the  project  company  to  outsource 
some activities currently handled by railways, including to the private sector.

(ii)  Construction  quality.  The  Government  will  cause  MOR  and  the  project 
company to ensure that the project railway is constructed in accordance with the 
Government’s national technical standards, and that construction supervision, 
quality control, and contract management are carried out satisfactorily. 
(iii)  Connecting railway lines. The Government will cause MOR and the project 
company to ensure that (a) capacity enhancement operations for connecting 
railway lines are completed by the commencement of commercial operations of 
the project railway; and (b) necessary measures are promptly taken to mitigate 
any  capacity  constraint  on  connecting  railway  lines,  identified  during  the 
operation of the project railway, to ensure the smooth flow of traffic generated by 
the project railway. 
(iv)  Container traffic. The Government will cause MOR to construct 2 extra-large 
container terminals in Urumqi and in Lanzhou, and container handling facilities at 
Longnan and Guangyuan by the commencement of commercial operations of the 
project railway. 
(v)  Supply of rolling stock. The Government will ensure that MOR and the project 
company provide sufficient rolling stock, at all times, for the effective operation of 
the project railway. 
(vi)  Safety. The Government will cause MOR and the project company to ensure that 
all safety measures are fully implemented with respect to construction, operation 
and maintenance of the project railway in accordance with relevant government 
laws and regulations. 
(vii)  Safety  dissemination.  The Government will ensure, through MOR, that the 
project  company,  in  cooperation  with  the  local  prefecture,  city,  and  county 
governments, formulates and implements appropriate public safety campaigns 
through media, public announcements, households, and schools to familiarize 
people living along the project railway route with safety issues related to railways. 
(viii)  Station access and link roads. The Government will cause the local prefecture, 
city, and county governments to (a) construct station access roads in a timely 
manner prior to the commencement of commercial operations of the project 
railway, and (b) apply ADB safeguard policies in the construction of such roads. 
(ix)  Financial  ratios  and  reporting.  The  Government  will  cause  the  project 
company to maintain, starting after the second full year of the commencement of 
commercial operations of the project railway, (a) an operating ratio of not more 
than 70%, (b) a debt service coverage ratio of at least 1.2, and (c) a debt-equity 
ratio  of  not  more  than  65:35  to  ensure  operating  efficiency  and  financial 
sustainability. 
(x)  Tariff and tariff study. The Government will ensure that MOR and the project 
company set the tariffs, with respect to the project railway, at rates sufficient to 
ensure full cost recovery including the management cost of the project company 
and  working  (operation  and  maintenance)  costs  of  the  project  railway, 
depreciation,  debt  service,  taxes,  and  a  reasonable  profit.  The  Government, 
through MOR, will also ensure that the project company carries out a tariff study 
6 months prior to the trial operation of the project railway and advises ADB of the 
tariffs applied during such trial operation. 
(xi)  Anticorruption.  During  project  implementation,  the  Government  shall  follow 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy, it being understood that ADB reserves the right to 
investigate  directly  or  through  its  agents,  any  alleged  corrupt,  fraudulent, 
collusive, or coercive practices relating to the Project. The Government will cause 
MOR to ensure that (a) a supervisory body is established for the prevention of 
undue interference in business practices, and adequate resources are made

RAILWAY SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Railway Sector Profile 
 
1.  Key Features. Despite government efforts to increase the country’s transport capacity, 
serious constraints and bottlenecks remain, especially in the road and railway sectors. By the 
end of 2007, the PRC’s railway system of 78,000 kilometers (km) comprised 63,600 km of 
national railways and 14,400 km of joint venture and local railways.  From 1978, when economic 
reforms were first introduced, to 2007, the PRC experienced sustained rapid economic growth. 
This resulted in a correspondingly rapid increase in demand for transportation. Passenger 
transport grew by 9% yearly and freight transport by 7.6% yearly during the period. Railways are 
the principal mode of freight transport in the PRC, accounting for 47.5% of total freight ton-
kilometers (ton-km) in 2006, followed by 27.9% for inland waterways and sea-to-shore shipping, 
21.1% for roads, 3.3% for pipelines, and 0.2% for civil aviation. Road traffic accounted for 
52.8% of total passenger-kilometers (pass-km), followed by railways with 34.5%, civil aviation 
with 12.3%, and coastal and inland waterways with 0.4%.  
 
2.  Recent  Developments.  To  minimize  transport  inefficiencies  and  eliminate  transport 
bottlenecks  that  constrain  efficient  economic  development,  the  Government  increased  its 
investment  in  transport  infrastructure  in  the  10th  Five-Year  Plan  (2001–2005)  and  the 
11th Five-Year Plan (2006–2010). Investment in transport infrastructure as a share of gross 
domestic  product  (GDP)  more  than  doubled  in  the  last  decade.  The  PRC  had  invested 
CNY308 billion in capital construction to build 6,458 km of new lines, provide 3,275 km of 
double lines, and electrify 6,259 km of tracks in the 10th Five-Year Plan. A World Bank study1 
indicates that total transport investment should increase to at least 3.8% of GDP to avoid the 
economic costs associated with transport constraints. The Government continues to accord high 
priority to transport infrastructure investments to meet the increase in transport demand. 
 
3.  Future Development Priorities and Outlook. Substantial investments in the road and 
railway sectors from both domestic and international financing sources, including the private 
sector, are envisaged in the 11th Five-Year Plan (2006–2010). The plan continues to emphasize 
railway  development,  and  seeks  to  accelerate  railway  construction.  It  envisages  (i) the 
construction of 17,000 km of new lines, and (ii) the double-tracking and electrification of 45% of 
the network length. The plan seeks to (i) build a dedicated passenger railway network by 
constructing  7,000  km  of  passenger-dedicated  lines  by  2010;  (ii)  develop  coal  transport

B.  Asian Development Bank Experience 
 
6.  Assistance  to  the  Sector.  ADB  is  the  lead  lender  and  has  focused  on  improving 
infrastructure in less-developed and poor regions to promote sustainable economic growth and 
reduce poverty. Since 1989, ADB has provided 15 loans totaling over $3.0 billion to help finance 
the construction of 1,921 km of new railway lines under eight local railway projects, 5,541 km of 
new railway lines under six national railway projects, and a sector-wide intervention to enhance 
safety on the PRC railway network. These projects have introduced modern technology and 
improved the efficiency of railway operation through institutional and structural reforms. ADB 
has also provided 14 technical assistance initiatives totaling about $6.6 million to promote the 
commercial operation of railways, establish corporate governance, achieve cost recovery, and 
improve railway management.  
 
7.  Evaluation of Assistance. The evaluation3 of ADB assistance to the transport sector in 
the PRC concluded that ADB’s program for railways was a success. The evaluation noted that 
in the railway subsector ADB strategic priorities were well-aligned with the PRC’s needs. Its 
overall focus on building railways using modern technologies addressed needs to increase 
railway capacity and reduce the persistent gap between supply and demand as quickly and 
efficiently  as  possible.  The  priority  given  by  ADB  to  improving  efficiency  and  commercial 
orientation, and its emphasis on restructuring and reforming policy was well matched to evolving 
institutional reforms in railways. Experience from completed and ongoing ADB-financed railway 
projects in the PRC shows strong commitment and generally satisfactory capabilities of the 
executing  agencies  for  project  implementation.  The  speed  of  implementation  has  often 
exceeded expectation at the time of appraisal. The executing agencies have generally complied 
with the loan covenants. Resettlement and environmental management have been carried out 
satisfactorily.  Audited  financial  statements  have  been  submitted  on  time,  and  the  audited 
financial statements have been found to be generally acceptable. Of ADB’s 15 railway projects, 
10 are complete, and 5 are under implementation. The projects highlight the need to (i) ensure 
that the executing agency established for project processing and implementation has adequate 
capacity; (ii) prepare realistic traffic forecasts; (iii) review constraints on traffic throughout the 
network, and the impact on project viability of existing and planned railway lines and other 
transportation  modes  that  may  compete  with  the  project  facilities;  and  (iv) finance  railway

C.  ADB Strategy 
 
8.  Strategy  and  Priorities.  ADB’s  strategy  for  the  railway  sector  has  three  broad 
objectives:  (i) improve  economic  efficiency,  (ii) promote  growth  in  poor  inland  provinces  to 
reduce poverty, and (iii) protect the environment and manage natural resources. In pursuit of 
these  three  objectives,  the  strategy  supports  the  development  of  efficient  and  integrated 
transport networks to meet the needs of a growing market economy and contribute to reducing 
poverty through investment targeting poorer areas, coupled with policy and institutional reforms. 
Because of the importance of railway transport for the development of the national economy, 
ADB’s  strategy  for  the  railway  sector  is  focused  on  (i) expanding  the  railway  system  by 
constructing new lines in unserved areas that are less developed and poor, (ii) modernizing and 
increasing the capacity to improve transport efficiency on key routes of the national railway 
system, (iii) commercializing railway operations to sustain efficient operations, (iv) promoting 
energy  conservation  and  environmental  sustainability,  and  (v) increasing  railway 
competitiveness in the transport system through restructuring and reform.  
 
9.  Poverty Reduction. To heighten the poverty reduction impact of transport investments, 
ADB  pays  particular  attention  to  four  issues:  (i) locating  ADB-financed  projects  in 
less-developed  and  poor  regions  where  new  lines  will  stimulate  economic  development, 
(ii) encouraging the maximization of employment of poor people during project construction and 
operation, (iii) supplying local materials that meet the requirements of quality and economy from 
poor villages, and (iv) providing station access roads and link roads to widen the reach of 
project benefits to poor interior areas. 
 
10.  Governance and Policy Reform Agenda. The ADB policy reform agenda in the railway 
sector  is  contributing  to  the  restructuring  of  the  Ministry  of  Railways  (MOR),  the 
commercialization of operations, the increased management autonomy of railway operations, 
human resource  development, and improvements in financial management and accounting 
systems. ADB’s policy dialogue with MOR emphasizes the need for operational reforms for the 
rail  network,  including  enhancing  safety  in  construction,  operation,  and  maintenance.  ADB 
supports the safety and security objective on PRC railways through the introduction of modern 
technologies, policy development, legislation, monitoring, and outreach activities (Appendix 6). 
 
11.  Private  Sector  Development.  The  PRC’s  large  infrastructure  needs  require  local 
governments to shift from traditional financing modes to the capital markets. In the railway 
sector, a wider role for the private sector is envisaged. MOR has taken steps to create the 
conditions  necessary  to  attract  investments  in  the  project  facilities  and  services  from 
nongovernment and private sector sources. Possible areas include the construction of industrial 
sidings, commercial services, tourism, containerization, and parcel-related businesses. 
 
12.  Regional Cooperation. The PRC is an active participant in three regional cooperation 
initiatives: (i) the Greater Mekong Subregion, through Yunnan and Guangxi province; (ii) the 
Central  Asian  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC)  initiative,  through  the  Xinjiang

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The objective of the Project is to promote sustainable economic growth by enhancing 
transportation  capability  in  an  unserved  area,  thereby  creating  employment  and 
income-enhancing  opportunities,  raising  incomes,  and  reducing  poverty.  To  achieve  this 
objective, a corporate entity is being set up to construct, operate, and manage the Project; and 
assist in facilitating economic developments, such as tourism, as well as value-added and 
labor-intensive industries in the project area. The consulting services will assist in strengthening 
the institutional, marketing, and business development functions of the Project.  
 
B.   Scope 
 
2.  The consultants will (i) help with the institutional strengthening of the project company for 
its successful operation in a market environment; (ii) determine the level of tourism, industry, 
and  market  development  expertise  of  the  project  company;  (iii) research  programs  and 
incentives available for attracting tourist and related industry at the county, prefecture, and 
province levels; (iv) meet with a selection of potential shippers located or planning to locate 
along the route of the Lanzhou–Chongqing Railway (LCR); (v) meet with businesspeople of 
Lanzhou, Longnan, Guangyuan, and Chongqing to determine current operations and future 
inland transport requirements including those for export to the Greater Mekong Subregion and 
the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation countries and to Europe; (vi) develop plans for 
improving railway services for passengers (including tourists) and freight (particularly container 
services); (vii) propose measures to develop industrial sidings; and (viii) improve the marketing 
of railway services to targeted customers, both passenger and freight. The consultants will 
recommend  actions  and  changes  including  institutional  efforts  and  provide  capacity 
development support to make the project company more market-oriented and competitive. The 
international consultants will be recruited according to with Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time).  
 
C.  Expertise and Cost Estimates 
 
3.  About  10  person-months  of  international  consulting  services  will  be  engaged  using 
simplified technical proposal procedures based on quality- and cost-based selection (80:20 
ratio) in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The provisions of the 
ADB  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  will  be  included  in  all  invitation 
documents and contracts for international consultants. The international consultants will have 
expertise in institutional development, marketing, international trade, and railway operation. The 
loan  will  finance  the  services  of  the  international  consultants  and  a  capacity  development 
program, if necessary. 
 
4.  The Ministry of Railways and the project company will (i) assign appropriate counterpart 
staff  to  coordinate  with  and  facilitate  the  work  of  the  international  consultants;  (ii) provide 
suitable office accommodation and communications facilities commensurate with requirements; 
(iii) assist  the  international  consultants  in  scheduling  field  visits  and  discussions  with  field 
agencies  in  connection  with  the  study;  and  (iv) provide  all  facilities,  documentation,  and 
assistance as may be reasonably requested by the international consultants to complete the 
work.

OUTLINE OF THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has engaged the Ministry of Railways (MOR) on 
the key issue of enhancing energy efficiency on the PRC railways. The 11th Five-Year Plan of 
the Government identifies this as a key area for action and has requested MOR to take actions 
to enhance energy efficiency on the railway system. MOR has initiated some steps to achieve 
this; however, these measures are local and are not coordinated. A key aspect highlighted in 
discussions with MOR is the need for a sector-wide strategy to deal with this important issue, 
which would include taking stock of current consumption patterns and energy conservation 
measures, identifying the gaps, and recommending actions that can be taken by MOR. MOR 
has therefore requested ADB for a grant assistance to assist MOR in this important area. The 
technical  assistance  (TA)  will  assist  MOR  in  developing  a  strategy  for  enhancing  energy 
efficiency and energy conservation.  
 
B.  Scope 
 
2.  The study will (i) analyze the energy efficiency of the PRC railway sector, (ii) identify 
areas where energy efficiency can be improved, (iii) recommend actions and technologies that 
can be adopted, and (iv) develop a national railway sector energy efficiency strategy. It will help 
prioritize areas for enhancing energy efficiency and recommend a pipeline of priority lending 
projects for energy efficiency in the PRC railway sector, some of which can be supported by 
ADB.  
 
C.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
3.  International consultants, supported by national consultants, will be hired to implement 
the study. The consultants will (i) undertake a desktop study of available studies on the energy 
efficiency of the PRC railway sector, (ii) analyze the energy efficiency characteristics of the PRC 
railway sector and identify areas where energy efficiency can be enhanced, (iii) review recent 
technological developments and assess the most appropriate technologies for transfer to the 
PRC railway sector, (iv) undertake consultation with key stakeholders, (v) prepare a national 
railway sector energy efficiency strategy, (vi) prioritize investment areas and recommend a 
pipeline  of  priority  lending  projects  for  energy  efficiency  in  the  PRC  railway  sector, 
(vii) recommend a railway energy efficiency enhancement project that ADB could support, and 
(viii) provide  capacity-building  support  to  major  stakeholders  in  achieving  railway  energy 
efficiency. An international training program with participation from the relevant departments will 
be organized to allow the participants to learn from the experience of other railways abroad. 
Workshops and seminars will be organized to review and disseminate the findings of the study. 
The study will be undertaken in close consultation with the Government, MOR, and other 
relevant agencies. The study will build on ADB’s ongoing policy dialogue and will consider all 
previous studies by the Government, ADB, AFD, the World Bank, and other multilateral and 
bilateral agencies.  
 
D.  Cost and Financing

TRAFFIC FORECAST AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Traffic Forecast 
 
1.  Freight traffic for the Lanzhou–Chongqing Railway (LCR) was forecast by commodity 
(i.e.,  coal,  petroleum  products,  iron  and  steel,  fertilizers,  intermodal  containers,  and  other 
commodities) in two categories differentiated by their economic impact: (i) traffic diverted from 
other modes (other railway routes, and roads) on the basis of an assessment of the relative 
service and cost-competitiveness of the project railway; and (ii) generated traffic that would 
move only because of the existence of a railway line where none previously existed. The traffic 
forecast was based on a two-tier analysis: (i) national transport demand based on historical 
trends correlating socioeconomic parameters, such as gross domestic product and propensity to 
travel or ship or demand for railway transport; and (ii) national and regional railway traffic 
demand based on commodity-specific analysis for major commodities currently using other 
 
railway lines and roads. Traffic projections considered expected economic growth, population 
increase, tourism development potential, local government development plans, market surveys, 
and assessments of technical assistance (TA) consultants and the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) missions. The freight volume on the LCR is forecast to increase from about 40.14 billion 
ton-kilometers (ton-km) in 2015 to 88.58 billion ton-km in 2034, for an average annual growth 
 
rate of about 4.25%. Passenger traffic is forecast to grow from 10.70 billion passenger-km 
(pass-km) in 2015 to 34.19 billion pass-km in 2034, for an average annual growth rate of 6.3% 
(Table  A15.1).  Traffic  forecasts  are  considered  reasonable,  given  that  (i)  the  LCR  is  an 
important  link  connecting  northwest  PRC,  Central  Asia,  and  Europe  to  the  Chengdu–
Chongqing–Shanghai transport corridor, which also connects to Southeast Asia via Kunming to 
the  south,  such  that  transit  traffic  accounts  for  49.3%  of  total  freight  traffic 
(origin-and-destination pairs for major traffic movements include Urumqi–Kunming, Urumqi–
Chengdu, Alashankou–Chengdu, Jiayuguan–Chengdu, Jiayuguan–Geermu, Geermu–Chengdu, 
Urumqi–Guiyang, Urumqi–Yangang, Kunming–Wuwei, and Geermu–Chengdu); (ii) railways in 
the PRC have experienced high annual traffic growth with recent rates higher than the assumed 
growth rates for freight and passenger traffic; (iii) for about two-thirds of the length of the 
alignment,  there  has  been  limited  transport  infrastructure  developed,  with  the  result  that 
resources such as minerals have not been exploited, and there are already plans to tap these 
deposits once LCR is opened; and (iv) the average distance saved by routing traffic through 
LCR  compared  with  other  railway  lines  is  about  295  km,  and  over  600  km  for  two 
origin-and-destination pairs involving long-distance movement between eastern and western 
PRC.  
 
B.   Economic Evaluation  
 
2.  Alternative  Analysis.  As  part  of  the  economic  analysis,  possible  alternative 
interventions that would meet the growing transport demand in the project area under the 
national and provincial transport network plan were considered. Alternative analysis reviewed 
transport modes, alignments, and technical designs for various options. While enhancing the 
existing road capacity may be an option that would partly meet the increasing demand, it will not 
completely satisfy the various kinds of traffic, particularly bulk cargo such as coal over long 
distances to meet the needs of a growing economy. Aside from the higher initial cost, increased 
land requirements, high air pollution impact, fuel consumption, and user costs make the road 
alternative less viable. Several alignment alternatives were subsequently evaluated for line 
sections  on  the  basis  of  geologic  and  topographic  conditions,  terrain  considerations, 
consultations  with  community  representatives,  cost  estimates,  relative  impact  on  the 
environment and on resettlement, and integration with the national and local transport network.

The  technical  design  was  proposed  after  consideration  of  the  national  railway  network, 
consistency in the standards of contiguous sections at each end of the project railway, and 
forecast traffic.  
 
3.  Cost. The economic evaluation is based on a comparison of with- and without-Project 
scenarios, using constant 2008 economic prices. Under the with-Project scenario it is assumed 
that the diverted traffic (41.98 million tons and 12.24 million passengers in 2015) estimated 
under the with-Project scenario would continue moving by road and by existing railway lines. 
Furthermore, the generated traffic estimated under the with-Project scenario (26.98 million tons 
and 6.65 million passengers in 2015) would not materialize under the without-Project scenario. 
The project benefits and cost were revalued in economic prices by separating the cost items 
into tradable materials and equipment, non-tradable materials, labor, and land. The prices were 
expressed in yuan using the domestic price numeraire with a shadow exchange rate factor 
(SERF) of 1.01 for foreign exchange effects. A shadow wage rate factor of 0.67 was used to put 
an economic value on the wages paid to unskilled labor but not on wages for skilled labor, since 
there is no clear surplus of skilled workers.  
 
4.  Benefits. Economic benefits include (i) user cost savings for freight and passenger 
traffic; (ii) time savings for diverted passenger and freight traffic from buses, trucks, and other 
rail  lines;  (iii)  passenger  and  freight  transport  benefits  generated;  (iv)  tourism  benefits; 
(v) shipper  savings  due  to  increased  railway  competition,  (vi)  road  accidents  avoided; 
(vii) reduced pollution; (viii) energy savings; and (ix) national productivity benefits.  
 
5.  For passenger traffic diverted from road (5.08 million passengers in 2015), the user cost 
saving (CNY197.74 million in 2015) is the difference in the passenger economic fare between 
road and rail transport (CNY0.1271 per pass-km). For passenger traffic diverted from other LCR 
routes (7.00 million passengers in 2015), the user cost saving (CNY66.97 million in 2015) is the 
difference in route distance applied to the economic cost of rail passenger travel (CNY0.0123 
per pass-km). For passenger traffic diverted from air (0.15 million in 2015), the user cost saving 
(CNY32.35  million  in  2015)  is  the  difference  between  the  economic  cost  of  LCR  and  air 
transport (CNY0.3693 per pass-km). For generated passenger traffic (both local and interline) 
the estimated pass-km (3.6 billion in 2015) is multiplied by one-half of the average economic 
cost saving (CNY0.0845 per pass-km), and amounts to CNY307.16 in 2015. Passenger traffic 
time saving (CNY3.57 million in 2015) was computed only for diverted traffic.  
 
6.  For freight traffic diverted from roads (9.6 million tons in 2015), the economic benefit 
(CNY675.01 million in 2015) is the difference in shipper economic costs between road and rail 
transport (CNY0.1865 per ton-km). For traffic diverted from other railway routes to LCR, the 
benefit (CNY446.65 million in 2015) is the rail-diverted ton-km (26.93 billion in 2015) multiplied 
by the difference (CNY0.0166 per ton-km) between the economic rate of rail transport to the 
LCR economic rate. For generated freight traffic benefits (CNY6,708.73 million in 2015) an 
adjusted economic value-added ranging from CNY111.06 per ton for fertilizers to CNY2,440.74 
per ton for containerized cargo was computed on the basis of current financial value, nontax 
elements, SERF, percentage value added, percentage net taxes, depreciation, and operating 
surplus for each commodity. The adjusted economic values per ton represent the net economic 
value, i.e., the value of output at economic prices less the costs of production (sum of all 
intermediate input costs, wages, and annualized investment costs). Since generated traffic 
benefits represent producer’s surplus, one-half of the economic value for each commodity is 
multiplied by estimated generated freight tons. Similar to passenger traffic, freight traffic time 
saving (CNY3.65 million in 2015) was computed only for diverted traffic.

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
A poverty and social assessment (PSA) has been prepared for the Project. This includes a poverty profile of beneficiaries and

fieldwork, and secondary sources. Beneficiaries can be broken down into (i) direct beneficiaries, i.e., existing rail users, and 
other transport users who might shift to rail, such as freight carriers, and passengers; and (ii) indirect beneficiaries, who do not 
necessarily rely on the railway but may derive some benefits including those in public sector employment, operators of small 
businesses such as shop owners and traders, farmers and farmers’ associations or cooperatives, people engaged in daily 
labor, construction workers, and tourists visiting or transiting the PIA.  
Economic conditions along the alignment range from relatively well off to some of the poorest in the PRC. Most of the villages 
along the alignment are isolated and have not been recipients of development. The links between poverty, topography, and 
transport systems are apparent in the PIA. People living in the mountains or in isolated areas lack fertile land and sufficient 
means of livelihood. They also live in areas prone to drought, frosts, erosion, and uncertainty. The main causes of poverty in
